text:
In this video, you’ll see how you can 
modernize migrated servers with AWS
Application Migration Service (AWS MGN).

With this framework, you can easily 
configure disaster recovery, upgrade and
modify your host operating system,

and convert subscriptions to 
AWS-managed subscriptions.

We’ll begin at the AWS Application 
Migration Service console.

To get started, let’s navigate 
to the Settings page.

Here, we’ll create a post- 
 launch settings template.

To use this template, we must first 
activate the post-launch actions.

This allows MGN to install the AWS 
Systems Manager agent on newly

launched servers and execute 
the predefined actions.
Next, we’ll choose a deployment option.

Post-launch actions can be executed on 
test and cutover instances or cutovers only.

The first option is recommended so 
that the deployment is fully tested
before moving into production.

Next, we’ll select which 
modernization actions to enable.

The disaster recovery action installs the 
AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery Service
(AWS DRS) agent on each migrated server

and configures replication 
to a specified target region.

The operating system action 
converts any servers running the
open-source CentOS to Rocky Linux.

The third action changes a SUSE Linux 
subscription to an AWS-provided SUSE subscription.
Let’s build the template.

In this case, we’ll 
configure disaster recovery.

We must also select the region where 
our recovery instances will be deployed.

AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery service 
must be initialized for your account
in the region you selected.

We won’t enable the other 
two actions at this time.
Let’s save the template.

Here we can view the post- 
 launch actions we initiated.

The template configuration will be available 
for all new servers added to the console.

For source servers already replicating 
using AWS Application Migration

Service, we can revise the 
post-launch actions directly.
Let’s open one of our source servers.
We’ll view its post-launch settings.
Only the disaster recovery action is enabled.
Let’s edit the settings.

We’ll enable the conversion 
of CentOS to Rocky Linux.
Let’s save the settings.
The adjustment was saved.

Now we’ll launch a test instance to execute 
the post-launch actions for this server.
Let’s go to the Migration dashboard tab.
We’ll launch one test instance.
The execution can take some time.

Let’s review another test instance 
that we’ve already launched.

Viewing the Migration dashboard, we 
can track the lifecycle of the server and

monitor the status of its 
replication and post-launch actions.

Three post-launch actions 
executed successfully.

From here, we can drill down to further 
review the CentOS-to-Rocky Linux action.

The link brought us to the Systems 
Manager console, where we can
see the command that was run.
Let’s view the output for the target instance.
We can review the result of the conversion.

Each action in MGN is a public Systems 
Manager document that can be executed

on any AWS Elastic Compute Cloud 
(AWS EC2) instance we have running.
Let’s close the tab.

We can also view details of the disaster recovery 
initialization by going to the DRS console.

The DRS agent has been installed 
successfully on the instance, and is now
replicating to the recovery region using DRS.
This action was performed automatically,

with no manual setup involved 
in creating the server.

You’ve just seen how you can modernize migrated 
servers with AWS Application Migration Service.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it's your turn to try.
